text: Development of the mouth and GI tract in embryos Dr Christina Marth Lecturer marthc@unimelb.edu.au VETS30016 / VETS90120 Learning Objectives • Describe the derivatives of the primitive gut tube (fore-, mid-, hindgut) • Explain the developmental anatomy in the embryo of the mouth and associated structures, including the tongue • Discuss the developmental anatomy of the oesophagus, stomach and intestines Why? … in order to explain the orientation and relations between organs in adult animals. … in order to elaborate on the origin of common malformations. Where does it all start? Gastrulation Inner cell mass ≈ embryo Cross section McGeady, 2017, Fig. 11.6 (ad.) Senger, 2003, Fig. 13.4 (ad.) The primitive gut Cross section Longitudinal section Lateral body folding Cranial and caudal body folding McGeady, 2017, Fig. 18.2 (ad.) The primitive gut T McGeady, 2017, Fig. 18.2 The primitive gut • within the embryo: – Foregut – Midgut – Hindgut yolk sac • extraembryonic: – yolk sac – allantois Derivatives of the gut tube Derived from the foregut: • Parts of the oral cavity • Pharynx / Oesophagus • Stomach/ prox duodenum • Liver and pancreas • Thyroid / parathyroid/ thymus • Trachea and Lungs Derived from the hindgut: • Distal part of transverse colon to descending colon • Cloaca → anal canal / urogenital sinus Derived from the midgut: • Duodenum to transverse colon → think about blood supply! Embryology of the digestive system Learning objectives • Describe the derivatives of the primitive gut tube (fore-, mid-, hindgut) • Explain the developmental anatomy in the embryo of the mouth and associated structures, including the tongue. • Discuss the developmental anatomy of the oesophagus, stomach and intestines Derivatives of the gut tube Derived from the foregut: • Parts of the oral cavity • Pharynx / Oesophagus • Stomach/ prox duodenum • Liver and pancreas • Thyroid / parathyroid/ thymus • Trachea and Lungs Derived from the hindgut: • Distal part of transverse colon to descending colon • Cloaca → anal canal / urogenital sinus Derived from the midgut: • Duodenum to transverse colon → think about blood supply! Development of the Mouth Stomodaeum = ectodermal depression at rostral end of embryo Oropharyngeal membrane stomodaeumepithelium of mouth is ectodermal Oropharyngeal membrane = membrane composed of ectoderm and endoderm which separates stomodeum from foregut Formation of facial region Pharyngeal arches & Fronto-nasal prominence contribute to head and neck formation stomodaeum Fronto-nasal prominence McGeady, 2017, Fig. 22.1 (ad.) Fronto-nasal prominence • Gives rise to: – Frontal process – 2 lateral nasal processes – 2 medial nasal processes Frontal process McGeady, 2017, Fig. 22.3 (ad.) Fronto-nasal prominence Fronto-nasal prominence differentiation Frontonasal prominence stomodeum DIFFERENTIATION Noden, 1985 1st Pharyngeal Arch foregut = mandibular arch • Left and Right Maxillary process • Left and Right Mandibular process • Elongation of these processes forms the oral cavity McGeady, 2017, Fig. 22.4 (ad.)Noden, 1985, Fig. 9.7McGeady, 2017, Fig. 22.3 (ad.) Facial Development Processes fuse: • Upper jaw/ lips – Naso-medial processes + maxillary processes • Nose – Frontal process + naso-lateral processes • Lower jaw/ lips – Fusion of the mandibular processes Video showing facial development https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wFY_KPFS3LA Normal Species variation • Upper lip anatomy – Sheep- cleft upper lip – Carnivore -groove in upper lip – Horse/ cattle smooth upper lip Normal Species variation • Dolocephalic vs BrachycephalicWhich processes failed to fuse in this puppy? Development of the oral cavity (= primary palate) Caudal part atrophies Large tongue reaching into nasal cavity Oral cavity grows faster than tongue Sulcus between lips/ cheeks and gingiva forms McGeady, 2017, Fig. 22.5 (ad.) Division of the oro-nasal cavity Secondary palate derives from: • lateral palatine processes (2) • Maxillary process (rostral) Cleft palate • Failure of palatine processes (but not maxillary processes) to fuse • Serious consequences for suckling neonate Development of the tongue • Mesenchymal swellings: 1. Median tongue swelling 2. Two lateral tongue swellings 3. hypopharyngeal swellings • Arises from the floor of the pharynx atrophies McGeady, 2017, Fig. 22.8 (ad.) foregut Oropharyngeal membrane stomodaeum Development of the tongue • Mesenchymal swellings: 1. Median tongue swelling 2. Two lateral tongue swellings 3. hypopharyngeal swellings • Arises from the floor of the pharynx Body = ectoderm Root = endoderm atrophies McGeady, 2017, Fig. 22.8 (ad.) Vallate papillae Thinking about species differences… • Mesenchymal swellings: 1. Median tongue swelling 2. Two lateral tongue swellings 3. hypopharyngeal swellings • Arises from the floor of the pharynx atrophies McGeady, 2017, Fig. 22.8 (ad.) sulcus Thinking about species differences… • Mesenchymal swellings: 1. Median tongue swelling 2. Two lateral tongue swellings 3. hypopharyngeal swellings • Arises from the floor of the pharynx atrophies McGeady, 2017, Fig. 22.8 (ad.) Torus (cow) Embryology of the digestive system Learning objectives • Describe the derivatives of the primitive gut tube (fore-, mid-, hindgut) Explain the developmental anatomy in the embryo of the mouth and associated structures, including the tongue. • Discuss the developmental anatomy of the oesophagus, stomach and intestines Derivatives of the gut tube Derived from the fore-gut: • Parts of the oral cavity • Pharynx / oesophagus • Stomach/ prox duodenum • Liver and pancreas • Thyroid / parathyroid/ thymus • Trachea and Lungs Derived from the mid-gut: • Duodenum to transverse colon Derived from the hind-gut: • Distal part of transverse colon to descending colon • Cloaca → anal canal / urogenital sinus McGeady, 2017, Fig. 18.2 (ad.) Formation of the oesophagus • Narrowed cranial end of the foregut • Elongation occurs during growth → Epithelium and glands are endoderm derived → Connective tissue and muscle layer are partially derived from mesoderm → Striated muscle derived from caudal pharyngeal arches Formation of the stomach • Midline spindle shape swelling of foregut Dorsal surface grows faster → greater curvature Ventral surface grows slower → lesser curvature LOCATION?! McGeady, 2017, Fig. 18.7 (ad.) Formation of the stomach • Stomach rotation – Rotates so that the greater curvature is first to the left and then caudo-ventral – Enlarged dorsal mesogastrium (mesoderm) elongates to form the greater omentum spleen Dorsal mesogastrium Lesser omentum Falciform lig. liver liver Omental bursa Greater omentum spleen For. epiploicum McGeady, 2017, Fig18.4 (ad.) Stomach rotation Video showing stomach rotation (starting at 1:42) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rSFsE_xAVps Ruminant forestomachs McGeady, 2017, Fig. 18.5 (ad.) Formation of the pancreas • Is derived from 2 primordia – Dorsal primordium from dorsal duodenum → left lobe – Ventral primordium from hepatic diverticulum → right lobe → gastric and intestinal rotation cause fusion McGeady, 2017, Fig. 18.8 (ad.) … explains species-specific duct system horses/ dogs/ humans: Pancreatic duct (from ventral lobe) → opens on major duodenal papilla Accessory pancreatic duct (from dorsal lobe) → opens on minor duodenal papilla sheep/ goats/ cats: Dorsal duct atrophies Cattle, pigs: ventral duct atrophies Derivatives of the gut tube Derived from the foregut: • Parts of the oral cavity • Pharynx / Oesophagus • Stomach/ prox duodenum • Liver and pancreas • Thyroid / parathyroid/ thymus • Trachea and Lungs Derived from the midgut: • Duodenum to transverse colon Derived from the hindgut: • Distal part of transverse colon to descending colon • Cloaca → anal canal / urogenital sinus Formation of small and large Intestine Initial gut tube is straight - dorsal/ventral mesenteries → ventral mesentery degenerates Dynamic changes: • Hair-pin shaped loop • Y.S. stalk at tip of loop Formation of small and large Intestine Dynamic changes: • Hair-pin shaped loop • Y.S. stalk at tip of loop McGeady, 2017, Fig. 18.7 (ad.) Yolk sac Formation of small and large Intestine ventral mesentery degenerates Dynamic changes: • Hair-pin shaped loop • Y.S. stalk at tip of loop • Physiological umbilical herniation Noden, 1985, Fig. 16.8 (ad.) Formation of small and large Intestine ventral mesentery degenerates Dynamic changes: • Hair-pin shaped loop • Y.S. stalk at tip of loop • Physiological umbilical herniation • Rotation/extensive coiling Noden, 1985, Fig. 16.8 (ad.) Midgut rotation McGeady, 2017, Fig. 18.9 (ad.) 180° Midgut rotation Video showing midgut rotation (starting at 5:19) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rSFsE_xAVps Species specific changes McGeady, 2017, Fig. 18.10 (ad.) Derivatives of the gut tube Derived from the foregut: • Parts of the oral cavity • Pharynx / Oesophagus • Stomach/ prox duodenum • Liver and pancreas • Thyroid / parathyroid/ thymus • Trachea and Lungs Derived from the hindgut: • Distal part of transverse colon to descending colon → caudal mesenteric a. • Cloaca → anal canal / urogenital sinus Derived from the midgut: • Duodenum to transverse colon Cloaca and proctadeum • Caudal blind ending expansion of hindgut endoderm → cloaca • Invagination of ectoderm beneath tail → proctodeum • Cloacal membrane = endoderm/ectoderm proctodeum Division of the cloaca 1, cloaca, 4, cloacal membrane, 5, urorectal septum 2’ anorectal canal, 4’, anal membrane; 4’’, urogenital membrane, • Lateral extensions form the urorectal septum (5) → separates hindgut/allantois → extends caudally → cloacal membrane(4) degenerates → separate anal/urogenital sinus openings Dyce, 2010, Fig. 3.66 (ad.)proctodeum Atresia ani McGeady, 2017, Fig. 18.14 (ad.) Embryology of the digestive system Learning objectives • Describe the derivatives of the primitive gut tube (fore-, mid-, hindgut). Explain the developmental anatomy in the embryo of the mouth and associated structures, including the tongue. Discuss the developmental anatomy of the oesophagus, stomach and intestines. Please use the discussion board for any questions!
